author: Alex Richards
title: Brain injury awareness campaigners implore Arsene Wenger not to rush back Arsenal star Hector Bellerin
text:
Brain injury awareness campaigners implore Arsene Wenger not to rush back Arsenal star Hector Bellerin The Gunners are taking no chances with the Spaniard, but he could return against Hull this weekend Share Bellerin on the field getting medical attention (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) Share Get Arsenal FC   Thank you for subscribing!   
Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger has been urged not to rush Hector Bellerin back into action by concussion campaigners. 
Bellerin has been on a specialist training programme at the club's London Colney training ground after colliding with Marcos Alonso during the weekend defeat to Chelsea. 
The Spaniard, 21, was caught in the face by his compatriot's elbow - before thumping to the floor - in his attempt to block the Blues' opening goal in the 3-1 loss at Stamford Bridge. 
Bellerin was unable to answer questions from Gunners' physio Colin Lewin immediately after the incident. 
The full-back was unaware of the score as Lewin sought answers during an on-field test, and was swiftly replaced by Brazilian defender Gabriel. Bellerin is hit hard by Alonso (Photo: IAN KINGTON/AFP/Getty Images) Hector Bellerin receives medical attention before being substituted (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Thierry Henry questions Arsenal player's mentality but says Wenger should STAY 
Arsenal are hoping Bellerin will be available to start this weekend when they host Hull, as Wenger's men look to get back to winning ways. Otherwise, Gabriel, a centre-half, will be asked to deputise. 
Bellerin has been away from the first-team in training for the first two days of this week, being monitored closely by the club's medical staff, as they seek to ensure that Bellerin is not suffering from a concussion. 
Club doctor Gary O'Driscoll, formerly of the British and Irish rugby teams, is currently in charge of assessing Bellerin and has campaigned for greater care when it comes to head injuries, and in particular concussion. 
He is also chairman of the Premier League club doctors' group, the panel that announced new rules regarding head injuries back in 2014. 
MRI scans have given Bellerin the all-clear and according to FA guidelines club doctors have the final say on his return to training. Arsenal doctor Gary O'Driscoll (Photo: Arsenal FC via Getty Images) 
A spokesperson for Headway, the brain injury charity, said: "We were pleased to see that after concussion was suspected, the protocol was followed and the player was removed from play. 
"Quite rightly, it appears he is going through the graduated return to play protocol. While this normally takes 14 days, the FA's rules state that if the player is in an enhanced care setting and as long as they pass all the necessary tests, they can return after six days. 
"If the player shows any signs or symptoms of concussion during this time, they will have to begin the process again. 
"Of course, regardless of how many days have passed, we would always advise the safety-first approach and recommend players do not return to play unless they are medically assessed as being fully fit to do so." Jeff Astle, whose death was down to injuries caused by heading old heavy footballs (Photo: Mirrorpix) Read More Sol Campbell says Arsenal lack leaders as former side look to have blown title chances 
Dawn Astle - the daughter of West Brom legend Jeff Astle, who died due to brain trauma injuries at 59, caused by heading footballs - believes Arsenal cannot afford to take any chances with Bellerin. 
"There is no room for error," she told the Daily Mail. "There is no room for risks. No risks should be taken at all. It's better to err on the side of caution. 
"I've watched the clip again. He's just out. People think of concussion, it is a bit of a wishy-washy word but it is a brain injury. 
"If his arm had been broken, people can see that. But you can't see what's happening to the most fragile, complex organ in the body that once it is damaged doesn't repair itself. It's so important.'
